author: jacobgadikian
content: I have a question, maybe some comments.  In the video, the presenter mentioned that overclocking could confer an advantage but we don't need to worry about attacks till amax is hit.

author: jacobgadikian
content:
My question isn't really about attacks, because I assume that amax is sufficiently high to ward off trouble.  But I guess that vdf rig operators are incentivized-- is the incentive large enough (or will it be large enough) to say, inspire a company (companies?l to make proprietary designs that outperform the open source one?

Is keeping the "commonly used" design open source a priority?

author: jacobgadikian
content: Thanks.  It was a pretty fascinating talk, and very interesting topic.  Will watch the second video now, and post here if I've got other questions.

author: jacobgadikian
content:
Yeah, so I guess my only question right now (though I actually have a ton of questions about eth 2.0 because I don't really understand it yet) is the one about:

If overclocking can confer a financial advantage over other honest participants, isn't it inevitable that proprietary (but totally honest) designs will show up on the market?

author: jacobgadikian
content:
I guess that's the answer to the question, right?

I bet it makes most sense to not even bother with an evaluation reward

author: sky.cactus
content: An evaluation reword is necessary if you want to have an idea of what the theoretical max VDF speed available on the market is.

author: sky.cactus
content: The higher the reward, the better the data.

author: sky.cactus
content: 0 reward means no knowledge.

author: jacobgadikian
content: Hm.  If it's used that way (to find theoretical max speed) I do reckon proprietary devices would crop up, as there would be an incentive to create them

author: sky.cactus
content: That is fine.  Generally VDFs are used where you want to *ensure* there is a minimum delay between two events, but without wasting a massive amount of resources on hashing power and hashing rewards.  In order to guarantee a delay, you need a mechanism for getting information about what the fastest VDF solver someone has built is.  To do that, you need to basically bribe VDF solvers to show their speed.

author: jacobgadikian
content: This is fun.  Just thought I'd mention that.

author: jacobgadikian
content:
So, yeah, if we don't care that proprietary designs would take over the initial open source design... Give a higher reward and you should get multiple competing highly optimized proprietary designs.  (Consider Bitcoin and whatsminer/Bitmain/caanan/strongu, who all have pretty good super  proprietary sha256 asics and whose businesses basically exist because of the block reward)

 Even a competitive open source design maybe?  Possibly with a rider in the license that allows audits and study, but prohibits other manufacturers from selling it?

Just hard to keep the design open once there's an incentive

author: jacobgadikian
content: Really interesting point about getting data

author: jacobgadikian
content: Hadn't even considered that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, the conflict here is open vs information asynchrony.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you have an open system with no incentive to "prove that you have done better than the open system", then if someone *can* do better than the open system you won't know about it, and you could end up with a situation where someone is able to do VDF computations at 10x the speed of the open design, but no one knows it and they are able to game the system because the system isn't calibrated to target that kind of VDF solving speed.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you have an incentive, then your open system will almost certainly *not* be the fastest, but you will very likely have a good idea of just how fast the fastest is.

author: sky.cactus
content: Depending on the use case for your VDFs, one system may be preferred over the other, but I don't think there is a solution to having confidence in the current VDF performance while also not incentivizing proof of performance.
